title: 114_hr2712
content: The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes provisions for a prospective reporting system and protection of dependent privacy. Congress aims to minimize compliance burdens while balancing the need for sufficient reporting to enforce the law and protect individual privacy. The Act mandates the implementation of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Treasury Secretary within 180 days. Employers can report essential coverage details for full-time employees through this system. The Act mandates a voluntary reporting system for employers to certify details of coverage offered to employees, dependents, spouses, and part-time employees. The certification must also confirm if the coverage meets minimum value requirements and affordability safe harbors. The Act mandates a voluntary reporting system for employers to certify details of coverage offered to employees, including availability, waiting periods, and compliance with affordability safe harbors. Information must be reported 60 days before the open enrollment period for each calendar year to ensure secure access by Exchanges, the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub, and the IRS. The Act mandates a process for employers to report employee coverage details for each calendar year, ensuring secure access for Exchanges, the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub, and the IRS. It includes processes for eligibility determinations for premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies, follow-up with employers for additional information, and timely updates to the system. The Act mandates a process for employers to report employee coverage details for each calendar year, ensuring secure access for Exchanges, the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub, and the IRS. It includes processes for eligibility determinations for premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies, follow-up with employers for additional information, and timely updates to the system. The system allows employers to provide timely updates regarding any cancellation of coverage or significant changes in coverage availability for participating employees. Employers using the system can be exempt from certain reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 if they meet specific criteria. Employers must meet reporting requirements under section 6056 of the Internal Revenue Code for the calendar year, and furnish statements to the IRS and employees who have enrolled in a qualified health plan through the Exchange or received premium tax credits. Employers may use third parties for filing without affecting their liability under the Internal Revenue Code. Exchanges must notify employers when an employee or dependent enrolls in a qualified health plan. SEC. 4 amends Section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow substitution of name and date of birth for TINs for dependents if not collected before 2014. Effective date is 60 days after enactment. SEC. 5 relates to electronic statements. Section 6056(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow electronic delivery of statements if consented to by the individual's employer. Section 6055(c) is also amended to allow electronic delivery of statements related to health insurance coverage if the individual has previously consented to receive private health information electronically. The amendments made by this section allow electronic delivery of statements related to health insurance coverage if the individual has previously consented to receive private health information electronically. Effective December 31, 2015, individuals shall be deemed to have consented to receive statements in electronic form if they have previously consented to receive electronic health records. The amendments allow electronic delivery of health insurance statements if consented to receive private health information electronically. Individuals are deemed to have consented if they previously consented to receive electronic health records. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding employees eligible for tax credits or subsidies from 2014 to 2016. The study will evaluate employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act from 2014 to 2016, focusing on data elements, notification process development, sufficiency of information provided to employers, total number of notifications sent, differences between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, and challenges encountered. The study will assess employer notifications by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act from 2014 to 2016, focusing on data elements, notification process development, information sufficiency, total notifications sent, differences between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, challenges faced, and recommendations. Additionally, it will examine if the Secretary of Health and Human Services has established a separate appeals process for employers to challenge eligibility determinations as required by the Act. The Comptroller General will conduct a study evaluating the prospective reporting system under the Affordable Care Act, focusing on information accuracy, employer participation, and implementation challenges. A report on the study results will be submitted to relevant Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018. The Comptroller General will evaluate the ACA reporting system, focusing on information accuracy, employer participation, and implementation challenges. A report on the study results will be submitted to Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION PROCESS FOR ACA SUBSIDIES. A marketplace can automatically reenroll an individual in a qualified health plan if eligibility for subsidies is redetermined annually, taking into account changes in premiums and income data. If the marketplace does not follow the specified processes, reenrollment with subsidies is not allowed until current income information is provided. The marketplace cannot automatically reenroll individuals in a qualified health plan with subsidies unless current income information is provided, following guidance from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. The marketplace must ensure that reenrollments for coverage and tax credits are consistent with guidance issued in 2015. Enrollees must maintain authorization for disclosure of information, provide updated income information annually, and receive timely notices for redeterminations and reenrollments. The term "marketplace" refers to State Based Exchanges and the Federally Facilitated Exchange. Enrollees receive timely notices about annual redeterminations and reenrollments.
